and I try to be on my laptop by 8:00am.

- [Harsh] I have a class
very early in the morning,
so I have to wake up for it.
I attend it and then I sleep again.
- [Darian] Get up.
- [Luke] Eat breakfast
- [Bill] Brush my teeth.
- [Darian] Go to the computer.

- [Anjali] I have like
four classes in the morning
and then I have lunch break.
- [Darian] Get your homework done.
- [Bill] Log into my computer.

And I just have to sit there
waiting for other people.
- [Luke] Eating lunch in the afternoon.
- [Juan] And then I read.
Read books.

- [Bill] Throughout the day
I have 10 minute breaks.

- [Harsh] And I can walk on
the roof terrace in my garden.
- [Anjali] I also enjoy playing the piano.
- [Juan] I work out.

- [Luke] I spend two
hours biking every day.

- [Juan] I navigate
through social networks.

- [Luke] Playing
basketball in the backyard.
- [Bill] If there was a virtual club
I'll do the virtual club.
- And have dinner.

- [Harsh] And then I have another
class in the evening time.

- [Bill] And then just
hang around and do nothing,
which is not really my lifestyle.
- [Harsh] And then I sleep.
(wheels turning on pavement)
(slow rock music)

- [Dr. Werner Vogels] Our
planets and our civilizations
are changing faster than ever before.
Join me as I've travel the globe,
talking to startup founders

using technology to make
our world more interesting,
accessible, and livable.

These are the entrepreneurs
that are creating the future
we will live in.
This is Now Go Build.
(tribal drumbeat)
For the last couple of years
my team and I has been quite fortunate.

We've been traveling the
world, meeting new people
and learning about surprising new ways

that people are using
technology to improve our world.

Well, in March, this season's
filming came to an abrupt halt
with the rest of the world.
We were in Asia

when COVID-19 came racing
down onto the stage.
By the time we left home,
the world was on lockdown.

Suddenly, we're all facing
the challenges of isolation,
shifting expectations in opportunities,

in both our personal
and professional lives.

Meeting new people seems
like a daunting endeavor.
Going to work
has a completely new meaning
as huge office spaces stand empty
and we learn to work from home.

Video conferencing has created
a new communication style
and work culture, virtually overnight.
Restaurants, music venues, theaters,
all standing empty as people who create
look to new ways to carry on creating.
But what about our students?

How do young people around
the world keep moving forward
not only with their studies
but also in connecting to peers?
If we learned anything in our travels,

it is that humans are
tenacious problem-solvers.

The innovators at
Brainly are no exception.
From their hometown in Kraków
and from mine in Amsterdam,
we got together to talk about
how they are solving this problem
for students around the world.

- Hey, Michał.
- Hey.

- [Werner] Hey, Bill.
- Hey, Werner,
nice to meet you.
- [Werner] Hey, good to meet you.

Thank you for taking
the time to talk to me.
- Thank you for the invitation.
- Tell me first what Brainly does.
- So, the inspiration for Brainly was
a study group between students.
So, imagine that there is a test coming
and there is someone who forgot
how to solve a specific equation
or to answer a question in biology.
And that person asks a question,

then friends gather
together to like solve it
and to help that person understand.

And that was our initial
inspiration for the product.
And from there, what we've built is

an online learning community
for students and parents,

where they can get help from
their peers or our experts.

- So, you have students
and you have your experts,
how can you be sure that your experts
are giving the right answers?

- So, in fact, it's a
peer-to-peer interaction.

So, we try to engage
students to also help others.

So, the idea is that you
would give help in topics
that you are really good at,
and that you are going to receive help
in topics where you struggle with.
And what we do on top of that

is that we add expert
verification of content.
And when there are the most popular
and most difficult questions,
experts answer questions as well.
All of that is aimed at

the asker understanding
how to solve this question
next time on their own.
(speaking in foreign language)

- We're limited to how
much social interaction
we can do with the world around us.
And that's just really difficult.
- Many of my extracurricular activities,
such as basketball, tennis, piano, math,
that all went either gone temporarily,
or it was moved completely online.
- Really makes me appreciate things that,
how they were before those little things,
being able to go to school

being able to get ice
cream with your friends.
- It's hard to stay motivated
to even do something.
It's weird.
You're bored,
you want to do something

but then you don't have
the motivation to do it.

- [Werner] So, you guys
started off in Poland?
- [Michał] Yes.

- Quite successfully,
rather quickly was it?
- Yeah, in fact it was,

the initial launch we
were struggling a bit.

You know, I think back
then almost no one believed
that students are going to help others.

On the first day when we've
seen that students ask
and help each other,

we were like, "Oh, wow!
It's really working."

That it's this peer-to-peer
community of people
helping each other.
And the path was crazy.

From 1 million users after
about a year since launch

to like 250 million
monthly users right now.
- [Werner] Wow.
So, what's an American doing in Kraków?
(laughing)

- That's the most common
question I get asked.

Hopefully, the answer
is making a difference.
- Have you seen changes that you,
as a technologist, needed to adapt to

that were different, let's say
in the past five, six months?
- Absolutely.

You know, in 2019 we
were doing 150 million
monthly unique users.

It scaled up to 250 million
in, by May of [2020].
You know, at 150 million

you pretty much have the
scale problems worked out.

There's a few things that
you need to pay attention to
but you're feeling pretty comfortable.

What happened for us was
not that we couldn't scale,
it was the speed at which we had to scale.
And usually we would have
three to four weeks to see it coming.

We were literally seeing
three to four hours of warning

before systems were
hitting failure points,
in these particular areas
where we made the conscious decision
not to try to auto-scale them.

- And of course, what I would
call the important other side
of how auto-scaling is scaling you down.
Yeah, because if you can scale stuff down,
anything that you don't pay helps you.
- Yeah, absolutely.
(slow hip hop music)
(speaking in foreign language)
(slow guitar music)
- Learning from home is not going to be
what you get from learning at school.
- If you're taking AP classes,

honors classes, accelerated
classes, any high level classes

you know that virtual school
is going to be more difficult.

For instance, here, our
class time is actually cut.
So, we almost have an hour cut off
from the normal school day.

And it just gives us less
time to learn the material,
less time to ask questions to the teacher.

- If I wanted personal help
during remote learning,
I would have to email my teacher

and it would still be very
hard for them to help me

because they can't
interact with me in person.
I think a lot of us have made it work

but there's still a lot
of students out there
who need that in-person learning.

- One of the biggest deals
of the lockdown has been,
of course, kids not coming to school.
And next to the social part of that
and the development part

definitely couldn't ask
anyone around school
anymore about answers.

- Yes. So, we try to
support students and parents
in this transition specifically.
On parents' side, what happens is that
parents became both teachers and students
and they didn't really sign up for that.

It was just the circumstances
that pushed them to do that.
So then, when you look at that situation

where they need to take
care of their kids,
they need to educate their kids

and then, they have to
maintain their jobs,
it's a lot of stress being put on parents.

- And what actually do
teachers think of all of this?
- Teachers use us in two ways.
One way is to help others

because at school they
can teach 30, 60 kids
but when they come to Brainly,
they can see, okay,
their content was reviewed 10,000 times.

So, they feel like, "Okay, I
just helped 10,000 students."

And the second use case is
that they come to Brainly
to check what questions are being asked

so they can see what
students are struggling with.

So then, they can adjust
their teaching at school
based on their research on Brainly.
- So, it is really supplemental
to sort of the traditional learning
that they may be doing in school.
- Correct.

And in fact, I think what
this situation showed
is how important is that core education
that you get at school,

that you build this
face-to-face interactions
with your peers.
In fact, there is a number of research
that is being created right now that

in fact, lack of this
human-to-human interaction
is not good for development of teenagers.

But what I think the online
education is great at doing

is that you can help to
personalize the experience,

like, "Okay, I really like
mathematics," let's say,

"and I want to advance
faster than my class."

but for example somebody
can be struggling with math
and they need to catch up,
but you know, teachers may not have
enough time to help them,
parents may not have time.

So then, they can have
online education services
that will help them to catch up.
So, what I think is happening
and the change that is being accelerated
by the crisis that we see right now,
that this access to high quality education
is going to equalize

because of the spread of
online educational products.
(slow instrumental music)
(speaking in foreign language)
- Human is a social animal
and we cannot survive alone
so it feels good to be among your peers
who have common interest
and you can discuss about things,
really fills up that space for me.

- [Luke] Everyone starts out
at a low number of points.

It gives you enough to
ask or two questions.
If you need to ask more questions

there's a whole front page
where you can answer questions.

You can get 10, 15 points per
question, sometimes even more.
And then, with those points
you can ask questions of your own.
It's like a video game,
but for learning.

And I really think that's
a great part about it.

- And because we use
that gamification system
like students, in fact,

can advance within the
system to become kind of
superstars within the product.

And because the baseline
of Brainly is that
We build community where smart is cool.

In fact, you know, the kids
who are helping the most

then become like superstars
of the community,

which then helps them to build
all of the social skills.

Right now they can interact
with many students.

They receive "Thank Yous"
from students that they helped

and that helps them to
build their confidence.
- Yeah. Suddenly the nerds are cool.
- Yeah.
Yeah. On Brainly definitely.
- Darn!
Darn, I wish I had this when I grew up.
(laughing)
(slow instrumental music)
You must be sitting there,
on a trove of data

that both teachers as
well as textbook writers
must be extremely interested in
because they need to know

where students really
have challenges with.

- Yes. In fact, we started
looking into these connections
with data to understand, okay,

if the student struggles
with this topic right now

we can predict that this
student is going to struggle
with this other topic later on.

So, how we can proactively
help them right now

to make sure that they avoid
these problems in the future.

- [Bill] When we start
to layer on top of that
an understanding of what types of things
a learner may be challenged with

we can start to identify
hotspots in educational gaps

for example, we can do
this with an overlay
of subject, age, region,
country of origin.
There's many ways to slice and dice it.

And that's a really
interesting perspective.
- It's changes in education,
driven by facts,
not by what people believe.
- Yeah. That's a great way to put it.
- It's a new initiative for us.
We started taking our first steps there
but I agree with you.

It's this mine of
opportunities that we can dig.
- Absolutely.
- It's quite crazy.

- Yeah. I'd like to spend a
week looking at your data,
see what we can get out of that.
It's very exciting.
(speaking in foreign language)
- This whole situation of being at home
has really put to the test on
how well you can manage your own time.

- I know so many students
that have said like,

"Oh I wish we could be
at school right now."

when a year or two ago, they
just want school to get out.

I just hope we have that
desire to be in class
now that we've learned the alternative.
(speaking in foreign language)
- Something I would like to keep in mind
when the pandemic is over,

is not to stress about such
little things like school,
like getting a bad grade here or there.
Seeing how this unexpected pandemic
just completely changed the world
and completely put everything at a halt.
It just shows me
how I often just get so stressed out
about such insignificant things.

- So Bill you've been in
educational technology
for quite a while now,
where do you see this going?

Are there big revolutions
around the corner?
- So, I think that the revolutions
have been a long time coming.
This is now an obvious problem
to more than just the insiders.
There are real gaps in terms of education
and technology's role in education
that people are now focused on solving.
I think we're gonna move beyond
just Personalized Learning,

which is the hot topic and sort
of the buzz word in Ed Tech.

I think we're gonna move
beyond personalized learning
to teacher enhancement ed tech products

where technology is a
partner for the teacher
in many ways that it's a partner today
for more traditional online businesses.

We have a whole language
and a whole way of working

that's all around data that
informs us what's important.

And we don't have those
same tools in education.
I sort of dream about these tools
like intervention recommendation systems.
We have content recommenders to help you,
buy a new widget or

buy an add-on for the
widget that you're buying.

But thinking about moving
that sort of technology

into the classroom and
having a struggling learner

who would benefit from a
tool that their teacher has

to say, "Hey, we're identifying
a potential problem.
Here's some recommendations
on how to move forward with this."

- Yeah, I think most,
especially those kids

that are failing or that
are having a hard time

they don't get noticed
until they have a hard time.
- Exactly.
(slow instrumental music)
- [Werner Vogels] It is undeniable
that we're in the middle of a transition.
The world we thought we knew before 2020
will never look that way again.

There's an opportunity in
the midst of this challenge

to shape the way things
will look in the future,
to shape the way we connect,
the way we see each other
and the way we spend our time,

in ways that are better than
the way they were before.
But for now, we do what we must.
Take care of each other
in even the simplest ways.
We put our brains together to innovate
to reach a better, new normal.
(slow instrumental music)
